Description: Papyrus; Egyptian language transliterated into Greek script containing some Demotic signs. The magical text has been interpreted as containing three spells pronounced against three demons to ward off fever or a charm for getting favour.
Curator's comments: As Greek became more dominant in Egypt, older texts could be rendered in a Greek script to help with pronunciation. This papyrus demonstrates the early part of this process. First, the nearest approximation in the Greek alphabet was used, for example θ for ‘th’. Later, demotic signs were added to express those Egyptian sounds that did not exist in Greek. Bibliography: J. Osing, Der spätägyptische Papyrus BM 10808 (AA 33), 1976 J. Dieleman 'Ein spataegyptisches magisches Handbuch: Eine neue PDM oder PGM?', in Res severa verum gaudia (Fs Zauzich; Leuven, Peeters 2004), 121-8. Hieroglyphs: unlocking ancient Egypt, pp. 164-5. Quack, J.F. 2022. Altägyptische Amulette und ihre Handhabung. Orientalische Religionen in der Antike 31. Tübingen, p. 159.
